Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: WIDER: EAGER: Increasing Faculty Use of Formative and Summative Assessment through Online Resources and Faculty Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to build a bridge between those professionals who provide physics instruction and researchers who develop assessment tools for physics. This is being accomplished by providing tools (online assessment resources and synthesis research) to arm faculty to do better assessment and professional development (a workshop and online support for physics department chairs) to teach chairs, as agents of change, how to use those tools.

This work will have three major outcomes:
1. Department chairs will learn to assess learning in their departments in a way that is consistent with their goals and language and connected to results in PER, thus meeting their need for assessment tools and transforming the way assessment is done in physics departments throughout the country.
2. Physics education researchers will increase their understanding of the assessment needs related to program review, resulting in improved tools to meet these needs and potential new areas of research.
3. Assessment will become a comfortable tool that will lead to increased adoption of evidence-based teaching. By arming chairs with good assessment practices tied to their needs and goals, this project will give them the tools to engage their departments in a systematic process of examination and improvement of teaching and student learning. The project will facilitate the connection between assessment and evidence-based teaching by connecting online assessment resources to existing resources for PER-based teaching methods in the PER User's Guide (http://perusersguide.org).

This project will achieve these outcomes by:
-- Developing online assessment resources including (1) a guide to the research behind and the use of many different types of formative and summative assessments, (2) a comprehensive collection of overviews of PER-based assessment instruments, and (3) a database system to collect and analyze results of research-based assessments.
-- Surveying chairs to identify the questions about assessment that are most important to them.
-- Developing an in-person workshop and online follow-up for department chairs on incorporating PER-based assessments.
-- Developing online modules and guides to address the questions identified by the survey.
-- Conducting synthesis research to analyze data collected through the new assessment results database and the existing rapid analysis and web reports (RAWR) system.

This project has the potential to transform how both assessment and teaching are done throughout the country by increasing the use of decades of physics education research. The impact will be maximized by targeting physics department chairs, who are already deeply motivated to do assessment for departmental and accreditation purposes, and are in positions of authority and able to affect departmental change. Assessment will start the transformation in an area where chairs are already eager for new tools and will lead naturally towards evidence-based teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The physics education research (PER) community has created a plethora of research-based assessments (RBAs) covering a multitude of physics topics. RBAs have been instrumental in improving physics teaching worldwide, as they give faculty a measure of the effectiveness of their instruction and allow them to compare their results to others. The PER community has also developed many research-based teaching methods, which faculty can use to improve their teaching and ensure the highest level of student learning, thus supporting a more scientifically literate general populace.

While there are many RBAs available, they have been hard to find and faculty face challenges analyzing and interpreting their results. This project created several online resources to help faculty access, use, troubleshoot, analyze and interpret the results of RBAs in order to improve their teaching. These resources are housed on PhysPort (physport.org), a website that supports physics faculty in implementing research-based teaching and assessment in their classrooms, by providing expert recommendations about teaching methods, assessment, and results from PER.

The products of this project include a directory of approximately 50 RBAs in physics, which helps faculty find the RBA most appropriate for their course. Each RBA has a detail page including example questions, synthesis of research, typical results and the option to download the RBA. The six most popular RBAs have an implementation guide with guidance on using the RBAs (content, course level, timing, access, versions, clusters, details on scoring, typical results and interpretation of results) and background (similar tests, variations, research on the development and use of the test and developers). We have also written expert recommendations containing answers to common questions faculty have about using research-based assessment in general. Finally we have developed a Data Explorer (physport.org/dataexplorer) that enables faculty to easily upload their RBA results and get automatic analysis of results and information on interpreting their results in order to improve their teaching. The Data Explorer collects the uploaded RBA results into a national database to which faculty can compare their own results in order to understand how effective their teaching methods are. Further, the Data Explorer will serve as a model for other disciplines to implement similar systems.

In order to create resources that meet real physics faculty needs, we interviewed physics faculty and department heads to find out what kinds of assessment resources or help with existing assessment interest faculty most. We synthesized the results into five different archetypes of faculty, and then designed resources to meet the specific needs of these types of faculty members. We also analyzed our interviews to identify themes for faculty and department head needs and wants around research-based assessment. This work helps guide physics education researchers to develop additional resources that faculty really want and will use.
